keyTakeAways: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges.
Santos claims his prosecution was not political and that he has accepted a 'very large slice of humble pie' during his time in prison.
He was previously serving a seven-year term, including time in solitary confinement, and is now no longer required to pay fines, restitution, or meet probation conditions.
Critics, including New York Reps. Nick LaLota and Andrew Garbarino, argue that Santos committed fraud, defrauded an election, and should face more than a brief prison term.
Santos says he has no remorse and that his crimes were not fraud, claiming the investment was made to win a political race.
He now intends to focus on prison reform and has expressed interest in working with the president on reform efforts, not in a partisan manner.
Santos stated he does not plan to return to politics in the next 10 years, saying he is 'all politicked out' at age 37.
The commutation of Santos's sentence has sparked debate over the fairness and political implications of executive clemency in U.S. politics.

summaryOfNewsArticle: George Santos, the disgraced former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges. Santos dismissed criticism, claiming the prosecution was not political and that he has accepted a significant amount of personal accountability. He expressed no remorse, defended his actions as part of a political campaign, and stated he will not return to politics in the next decade. Critics, including New York Representatives Nick LaLota and Andrew Garbarino, argue that Santos defrauded an election and deserves more than a brief prison term. Santos now intends to focus on prison reform, citing the negative impact of solitary confinement, and expressed interest in bipartisan efforts to improve the justice system.
title: George Santos maintains his prosecution was political, says he’s had a ‘very large slice of humble pie’
